SLMcontroller package

Submodules

SLMcontroller.FlatnessCorrection module

FlatnessCorrection.py: Generates a tab used to load an optical flatness correction element (this is usually a 8bit image given by the SLM producer).

class SLMcontroller.FlatnessCorrection.FlatnessCorrectionTab(pattern_generator, settings_manager, hologram_manager)[source]

Bases: QWidget

Generates a tab used to load an optical flatness correction element (this is usually a 8bit image given by the SLM producer). .. attribute:: pattern (

numpy.ndarray:): Array containing the loaded flatness correction image.

pattern_generator (

Pattern_generator:): Pattern generator object used to generate the flatness correction image.

settings_manager (

SettingsManager:): Settings manager object used to get the SLM resolution.

hologram_manager (

HologramsManager:): Hologram manager object used to update the SLM window.

image_data (

numpy.ndarray:): Array containing the loaded flatness correction image.

Path to the loaded flatness correction image.

Type:

str

scale

Scale used to display the flatness correction image.

Type:

int

Path to the folder containing the script.

Type:

str

SLM X resolution.

Type:

int

SLM_y_res

SLM Y resolution.

Type:

int

Init_GUI()[source]

Generates the GUI elements of the tab.

The tab contains: - A text field to enter the path to the flatness correction image. - A button to load the flatness correction image. - A checkbox to activate the flatness correction. - An image preview of the flatness correction image.

Returns the flatness correction image.

Returns:

numpy.ndarray: Array containing the flatness correction image.

Returns:

True if the flatness correction element is active, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

update_pattern()[source]

Updates the flatness correction image loading it from a file

SLMcontroller.FourierWavefrontOptim module

FourierWavefrontOptim.py: Uses the camera to correct for aberrations using a Fourier-based algorithm. The algorithm is based on: https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnano.2022.998656/full

SLMcontroller.Grating module

Grating.py: Generates a tab used to control an optical grating element. The grating can be rotated and its line density can be changed.

class SLMcontroller.Grating.GratingTab(pattern_generator, settings_manager, hologram_manager)[source]

Bases: QWidget

Generates a tab used to control an optical grating element. The grating can be rotated and its line density can be changed. The grating is generated using the GenerateGrating function of the PatternGenerator class. The grating will depend on the selected wavelength and SLM pixel pitch.

pattern (

numpy.ndarray:): Array containing the generated grating.

pattern_generator (

Pattern_generator:): Pattern generator object used to generate the grating.

settings_manager (

SettingsManager:): Settings manager object used to get the wavelength, SLM resolution and SLM pixel pitch.

hologram_manager (

HologramsManager:): Hologram manager object used to update the SLM window.

minlmm

Minimum number of lines per mm that can be used to generate the grating.

Type:

float

maxlmm

Maximum number of lines per mm that can be used to generate the grating.

Type:

float

lmm

Number of lines per mm used to generate the grating.

Type:

float

angle

Angle of the grating in radians.

Type:

float

lastvals

List containing the last values of the angle, lmm, wavelength, pixel pitch, X resolution and Y resolution used to generate the last grating (used to avoid re-generating gratings).

Type:

list

get_pattern()[source]

Returns the grating pattern.

init_GUI()[source]

Generates the GUI elements of the tab. The tab contains: - A slider and a spinbox to control the number of lines per mm of the grating. - A slider and a spinbox to control the angle of the grating. - A checkbox to activate the grating. - A checkbox to enable live updating of the grating. - An image preview of the grating.

is_active()[source]

Returns the state of the isactive checkbox.

make_angle_slider()[source]

Generates the slider and spinbox used to control the angle of the grating and adds them to the GUI.

make_image_preview()[source]

Generates the image preview of the grating.

make_lmm_slider()[source]

Generates the slider and spinbox used to control the number of lines per mm of the grating and adds them to the GUI.

needs_updates()[source]

Checks if the grating needs to be re-generated.

Returns:

True if the grating needs to be re-generated, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

update_angle_slide()[source]

Updates the angle of the grating when the slider is changed (usually called from the spinbox valueChanged signal)

update_angle_spin()[source]

Updates the angle of the grating when the spinbox is changed (usually called from the slider valueChanged signal)

update_lmm_slide()[source]

Updates the number of lines per mm of the grating when the slider is changed (usually called from the spinbox valueChanged signal)

update_lmm_spin()[source]

Updates the number of lines per mm of the grating when the spinbox is changed (usually called from the slider valueChanged signal)

update_pattern()[source]

Updates the grating pattern.

class SLMcontroller.Lens.LensTab(pattern_generator, settings_manager, hologram_manager)[source]

Bases: QWidget

Generates a tab used to control an optical lens element. The lens is generated using the GenerateLens function of the PatternGenerator class. The lens will depend on the selected wavelength, focus and SLM pixel pitch.

hologram_manager (

HologramsManager:): Hologram manager object used to update the SLM window.

Minimum focus distance that can be used to generate the lens.

Type:

float

maxfocus

Maximum focus distance that can be used to generate the lens.

Type:

float

focus

Focus distance used to generate the lens.

Type:

float

lastvals

List containing the last values of the focus, wavelength, pixel pitch, X resolution and Y resolution used to generate the last lens (used to avoid re-generating lenses).

Type:

list

get_pattern()[source]

Returns the lens pattern.

Returns:

numpy.ndarray: Array containing the lens pattern.

init_GUI()[source]

Generates the GUI elements of the tab.

The tab contains:

  • A slider and a spinbox to control the focus distance of the lens.

  • A checkbox to activate the lens.

  • A checkbox to enable live updating of the lens.

  • An image preview of the lens.

Checks if the lens is active (should be added to the rendered holograms)

Returns:

True if the lens is active, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

Generates the image preview of the lens.

needs_updates()[source]

Checks if the lens needs to be updated.

Returns:

True if the lens needs to be updated, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

update_lens_slide()[source]

Updates the focus distance of the lens when the spinbox is changed.

update_lens_spin()[source]

Updates the focus distance of the lens when the slider is moved.

update_pattern()[source]

Updates the lens pattern.

SLMcontroller.Meshing_process module

Meshing_process.py: Meshing process class. Used to handle gmesh GUI on OS that do not allow to run gmsh in a separate thread

class SLMcontroller.Meshing_process.MeshingHandler(eventsDict, conditionsDict, queue, SLM_x_res, SLM_y_res, algorithm, F)[source]

Bases: Process

Meshing process class. Used to handle gmesh GUI on OS that do not allow to run gmsh in a separate thread. This takes care of initializing gmsh and generating the mesh according to the user parameters. Given a mesh it parses it in a np.array structure where each element has associated its meshID and returns it to the main thread.

eventsDict

Dictionary containing all the events used to communicate with the main thread.

Type:

dict

conditionsDict

Dictionary containing all the conditions used to communicate with the main thread.

Type:

dict

queue

Queue used to communicate with the main thread.

Type:

multiprocessing.Queue

SLM_x_res

SLM horizontal resolution.

Type:

int

SLM_y_res

SLM vertical resolution.

Type:

int

algorithm

Meshing algorithm to use.

Type:

int

F

Meshing parameter (equation for meshing, see gmsh guide).

Type:

float

algorithms

List of available meshing algorithms.

Type:

list

algorithms_names

List of available meshing algorithms names.

Type:

list

isMeshed

True if the meshing process was already done, False otherwise.

Type:

bool

wasINIT

True if gmsh was already initialized, False otherwise.

Type:

bool

Enabled

True if the process should keep running, False otherwise.

Type:

bool

checkLoadedMeshSize()[source]

Checks if the loaded mesh fits the SLM size.

checkUserMeshing()[source]

Checks if the user requested a meshing operation (remesh, closeGUI etc.) and performs it.

getVariablesInQueue()[source]

Loads parameters from the queue (from the main thread).

init_GMESH()[source]

Initializes gmsh + creates basic geometry for the meshing.

loadMeshFromFile()[source]

Loads a mesh from a file.

parseMesh()[source]

Parses the mesh and returns it to the main thread. Converts from a gmsh to a numpy array where each element has associated its meshID.

reconstructMesh()[source]

Deletes anre reconstructs the mesh + geometry.

redomesh()[source]

Redoes the meshing operation.

run()[source]

Main function of the MeshingHandler class.

saveMeshToFile()[source]

Saves the mesh to a file.

showMeshGUI()[source]

Shows the loading GUI. This is not necessary, but it allows the gmsh GUI to appear on top of the main GUI.

updatebar()[source]

Updates the loading bar. The loading bar is extremely unnecessary. I had to add it as otherwise gmsh would not appear on top of the main GUI. This trick allows the gmsh GUI to appear on top of the main GUI and immediately visible to the user.

SLMcontroller.Remote_control module

Remote_control.py: Generates a remote control for the SLM.

class SLMcontroller.Remote_control.NetworkManager(app, **configs)[source]

Bases: object

Class used to manage the remote control of the SLM. Remote control is done through an HTTP server trying to be as RESTful as possible (but so far, miserably failing) Based on Flask.

app

Flask app used to manage the remote control.

Type:

Flask

add_endpoint(endpoint=None, endpoint_name=None, handler=None, methods=['GET'], *args, **kwargs)[source]

Adds an endpoint to the Flask app.

Parameters:

  • endpoint (str, optional) – Endpoint to add. Defaults to None.

  • endpoint_name (str, optional) – Name of the endpoint. Defaults to None.

  • handler (function, optional) – Function to call when the endpoint is called. Defaults to None.

  • methods (list, optional) – Allowed methods for the endpoint. Defaults to [‘GET’].

before_request(address='127.0.0.1')[source]

Decorator used to limit the access to the server to a specific IP address.

Parameters:

address (str, optional) – Allowed IP address for connection. Defaults to ‘127.0.0.1’.

Returns:

If the IP address is not the allowed one.

Return type:

abort(403)

configs(**configs)[source]

Sets the configuration of the Flask app.

run(**kwargs)[source]

Runs the Flask app.

send_image(image, name)[source]

Sends an image to the client. Used for remote check of the hologram.

Parameters:

  • image (image/PNG) – Image to send.

  • name (string) – Filename of the image.

Returns:

HTTP response containing the image.

Return type:

send_file

LUT_tab()[source]

Creates a new LUT tab and adds it to the tabwidget. .. todo:: Implement LUT tab

Spot_optim()[source]

Creates a new SpotOptimTab tab and adds it to the tabwidget. The spot optimization algorithm used in the SpotOptimTab is based on https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnano.2022.998656/full This algorithm relies on a camera to measure the spot intensity where aberrations should be reduced.

Spot_optim_ext()[source]

Creates a new SpotOptimTab_ext tab and adds it to the tabwidget. The spot optimization algorithm used in the SpotOptimTab_ext is based on https://www.nature.com/articles/nphoton.2010.85 The algorithm relies on an external feedback for the spot intensity measurement. The algorithm steps and parameters can be controlled remotely on the network using the following endpoints: - /optimiser/start : starts the algorithm (if already running, triggers a next step) - /optimiser/nextStep : triggers the next step of the algorithm (once scaned till the end of the phase pattern, this will return phase = null) - /optimiser/refzone : returns the current reference zone - /optimiser/refzone/<refzone> : sets the reference zone to <refzone> - /optimiser/probzone : returns the current probe zone - /optimiser/probzone/<probzone> : sets the probe zone to <probzone> - /optimiser/phase : returns the current phase - /optimiser/phase/<phase> : sets the phase to <phase> - /optimiser/phaseStep/<phaseStep> : sets the phase step to <phaseStep> - /optimiser/IDsList : returns the list of IDs of the active optical elements - /optimiser/phasePattern : returns the current phase pattern

add_endpoint_connections(tab)[source]

Adds the endpoints connections to the Flask app

Parameters:

tab (WavefrontOptim.SpotOptimTab_ext) – SpotOptimTab_ext object (for now the only tab that uses the endpoints)

QTabWidget

RenormalizePattern()[source]

Corrects for the non-linearities of the SLM. For each wavelenght the maximum uint8 phase value is usually given by the company but can also be measured e.g. at 760nm 255(2pi) —> 226(new 2pi value) So we need to renormalize the hologram such that value%226

Adds an optical element to the list of active optical elements

getPhasePatternIMG()[source]

Returns the phase pattern currently being rendered on the SLM in PNG image format for remote clients. Calls the NetworkManager.send_image which sends the contents of a file to the client.

Renders a phase pattern generated from an algorithm, bypassing the active optical elements

Parameters:

  • others (bool) – If True, the other active optical elements will be rendered on the SLM as well

class SLMcontroller.WavefrontOptim.SpotOptimTab_ext(pattern_generator, settings_manager, hologram_manager, meshing_process)[source]

Bases: QWidget

Spot optimization tab used to control the spot optimization process. The algorithm is based on https://www.nature.com/articles/nphoton.2010.85.

This code is meant to be controlled remotely from a separate acquisition system that will measure the intensity of the interference between probe and reference zones.

The control is done via Flask. The following endpoints are available:

  • /optimiser/start : starts the algorithm (if already running, triggers a next step).

  • /optimiser/nextStep : triggers the next step of the algorithm (once scaned till the end of the phase pattern, this will return phase = null).

  • /optimiser/refzone : returns the current reference zone

  • /optimiser/refzone/<refzone> : sets the reference zone to <refzone>

  • /optimiser/probzone : returns the current probe zone

  • /optimiser/probzone/<probzone> : sets the probe zone to <probzone>

  • /optimiser/phase : returns the current phase

  • /optimiser/phase/<phase> : sets the phase to <phase>

  • /optimiser/phaseStep/<phaseStep> : sets the phase step to <phaseStep>

  • /optimiser/IDsList : returns the list of IDs of the active optical elements

  • /optimiser/phasePattern : returns the current phase pattern

— Setting up the algorithm — First the user has to define the probe and references zones on the SLM. This can be done using gmsh. Mesh parameters and algorithms can be choosen in the tab. Once obtaining a satisfactory meshing this can be saved and loaded later. The mesh can be visualized using the gmsh GUI. This requires to start the GUI on another process as certain OS do not allow GUI to be started outside the main thread. The second process is started at the start of the program and kept dormant if not used.

It allows for an user to choose the parameters for 2 gratings:

  • one to “dump” the 1st order power of the SLM to an unused zone

  • one to that will be assigned to the reference and probe zones in order to scan for their interference

Once chosen the parameters the code will parse all the zones in the mesh and assign them a tag. The user can then choose the reference and probe zones from the GUI.

Starting the algorithm will allow to scan the selected reference zone phase offset in a range [0,2pi].

pattern_generator (

Pattern_generator:): Pattern generator object used to generate the grating.

settings_manager (

SettingsManager:): Settings manager object used to get the wavelength, SLM resolution and SLM pixel pitch.

hologram_manager (

setEventsHandlers(eventsDict, conditionsDict, queue)[source]
Sets the events handlers for the class.

As for the gmsh GUI process, Events and Conditions are generated in __main__ and passed to the class. Events are used to trigger actions in the meshProcess process (e.g. generate mesh, load mesh, save mesh, etc.) Conditions are used to synchronize the two processes (e.g. wait for the mesh to be generated before loading it)

Parameters:

  • eventsDict (dict) – Dictionary containing the events.

  • conditionsDict (dict) – Dictionary containing the conditions.

  • queue (queue) – Queue used to communicate with the gmsh GUI process.

start_algo()[source]

Starts the optimization algorithm. If the algorithm is alredy running, triggers a next step.

start_algo_rem()[source]

Starts the optimization algorithm remotely. If the algorithm is alredy running, triggers a next step. Unfortunately not all OS allow to use the start_algo function (as that will require to open new GUI windows) For this reason this is more or less a “Duplicate window” of the start_algo function.

Stops the optimization algorithm.

SLMcontroller.WavefrontOptim.load_pattern(mesh, grating, interf_grating, phase, SIZEX, SIZEY, refZoneID, probZoneID)[source]

Loads the phase pattern. Uses jit from numba to speed up the computation.

Parameters:

  • mesh (np.array) – Mesh used to separate the SLM in zones.

  • grating (np.array) – Offset grating pattern.

  • interf_grating (np.array) – Interference grating pattern.

  • phase (float) – Current phase of the reference zone.

  • SIZEX (int) – SLM X resolution.

  • SIZEY (int) – SLM Y resolution.

  • refZoneID (int) – Reference zone ID.

  • probZoneID (int) – Probe zone ID.

Returns:

Phase pattern.

Return type:

np.array

SLMcontroller.WavefrontOptim.next_step_fast(SIZEX, SIZEY, mesh, interf_grating, probZoneID, pattern, phase)[source]

Generates the next step of the optimization algorithm. Uses jit from numba to speed up the computation. This updates only the part of the pattern corresponding to the probe zone. In case the probe/reference zones have been changed load_pattern should be used instead.

Parameters:

  • SIZEX (int) – SLM X resolution.

  • SIZEY (int) – SLM Y resolution.

  • mesh (np.array) – Mesh used to separate the SLM in zones.

  • interf_grating (np.array) – Interference grating pattern.

  • probZoneID (int) – Probe zone ID.

  • pattern (np.array) – Phase pattern.

  • phase (float) – Current phase of the reference zone.

Returns:

New phase pattern.

Return type:

np.array

class SLMcontroller.utils.DoubleSlider(decimals=3, *args, **kargs)[source]

Bases: QSlider

doubleValueChanged

int = …, arguments: Sequence = …) -> PYQT_SIGNAL

types is normally a sequence of individual types. Each type is either a type object or a string that is the name of a C++ type. Alternatively each type could itself be a sequence of types each describing a different overloaded signal. name is the optional C++ name of the signal. If it is not specified then the name of the class attribute that is bound to the signal is used. revision is the optional revision of the signal that is exported to QML. If it is not specified then 0 is used. arguments is the optional sequence of the names of the signal’s arguments.

Type:

pyqtSignal(*types, name

Type:

str = …, revision
